nodes.metadata_json:
{"confidence":95,"prompt":"Implement the following plan:

# Bluesky Bot Implementation Plan

## Overview
Create a Bluesky bot that generates tweets using the Qwen3-8B fine-tuned model and posts them to Bluesky. Supports both manual CLI posting and scheduled automation.

## Files to Create

### 1. `bluesky_bot.py` - Main bot script
- Load Qwen3-8B model with LoRA adapters from `adapters_qwen3/`
- Generate tweets using mlx_lm
- Post to Bluesky using AT Protocol (atproto library)
- CLI interface with argparse for manual posting

### 2. `.env.example` - Environment template
- `BLUESKY_HANDLE` - Bluesky handle (e.g., user.bsky.social)
- `BLUESKY_APP_PASSWORD` - App password for authentication

### 3. `requirements.txt` - Dependencies
- `mlx-lm` (already installed)
- `atproto` - Official AT Protocol SDK for Python
- `python-dotenv` - For loading .env files
- `schedule` (optional) - For scheduled posting

Also add deciduous to this project and log all choices etc."}

{"confidence":85,"prompt":"take the code here, that we have set up for running this bot on bluesky.

We want to write it in rust and make it be a .app that we can just drop into the applications folder on my mac

it should do the same exact stuff and have the same exact credentials except it will have a GUI to see the posts and a button to manually post one and a slider to adjust the timing of the posting

make it in a separate directory/repo

use deciduous to track all work

be detailed 

use rust tools to give yourself good guard rails

functional core / imperative shell

make sure to make each major feature on a branch then merge it 

dont lose the narratives if you revisit something mark it fast and early

then we want to have a way to make it a startup program or disable that in the GUI too"}

nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":85,"prompt":"The Python bot works but spawns a new Python process for each generation, loading 5GB of weights every time. I want to run GPU-accelerated LLM inference natively in Elixir - load once, serve forever via GenServer. No Python subprocess calls at runtime."}

nodes.title: Choose GPU inference approach for Elixir
Bumblebee + EXLA - standard Elixir ML approach
MLX via Rustler NIF using mlx-rs crate
EXLA does NOT support Apple Metal GPU - only cpu, cuda, rocm, tpu
mlx-rs crate v0.25.1 exists with MLX bindings but immature for complex models
Chose NIF approach after EXLA eliminated - mlx-rs or EMLX

Build Bluesky Firehose Viewer in Elixir/Phoenix
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"elixir-phoenix","confidence":90,"prompt":"Build a Bluesky Firehose Viewer in Elixir/Phoenix with LiveView.

**Working Directory:** /Users/robertgrayson/code/firehose-worktrees/elixir

**CRITICAL: Use deciduous to log your work. You are on branch elixir-phoenix.**

## Requirements

1. **Create a new Phoenix LiveView application** in the working directory
2. **Connect to Jetstream WebSocket** at `wss://jetstream1.us-east.bsky.network/subscribe`
3. **Use websockex** for WebSocket client connection
4. **Display live messages** in a scrolling container
5. **Implement filtering** via form (collection type, operation, text search)"}

nodes.title: Creating TypeScript Bluesky Firehose Viewer with Express/WebSocket
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"typescript","confidence":85,"prompt":"Build a Bluesky Firehose Viewer in TypeScript with native WebSocket support.

**Working Directory:** /Users/robertgrayson/code/firehose-worktrees/typescript

**CRITICAL: Use deciduous to log your work. You are on branch typescript.**

## Requirements

1. **Create a Node.js/Express application** with WebSocket support
2. **Connect to Jetstream WebSocket** using native ws library
3. **Display live messages** via WebSocket to browser
4. **Implement filtering** via form (collection type, operation, text search)

## Jetstream API Details

- Endpoint: `wss://jetstream1.us-east.bsky.network/subscribe`
- Query params: `wantedCollections` (filter by NSID like `app.bsky.feed.post`)
- Message format:
```json
{
  "did": "did:plc:...",
  "time_us": 1725911162329308,
  "kind": "commit",
  "commit": {
    "operation": "create",
    "collection": "app.bsky.feed.like",
    "rkey": "...",
    "record": { "$type": "...", "text": "...", "createdAt": "..." }
  }
}
```"}

nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"I want to ensure that we use PURE ELIXIR for my post generator. It was stuck in an uncanny valley making too many cat posts and shoving in weird emojis. The python version was better. BUT WE CANNOT USE PYTHON IT IS PURE VILENESS we must do this only in Elixir but get just as good results. We were trying LoRA. Why doesnt LoRA work in bumblebee? We can patch ANYTHING and write what we need to support this, walk me through it and lets figure out how to get the elixir posts out of that uncanny valley."}

Runtime LoRA vs Fused Model for LLM inference
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":95,"prompt":"Critical architecture decision: The fused model approach (merge LoRA into base weights, then re-quantize to 4-bit) was destroying fine-tuning signal. The question was whether to:
1. Keep using fused model and accept quality loss
2. Apply LoRA at runtime in fp32 to preserve precision

This is THE key insight that fixed the "uncanny valley" quality issues."}

nodes.title: Fused model - merge LoRA into base, re-quantize to 4-bit
Runtime LoRA - apply adapters in fp32 at inference time
Chose runtime LoRA - base(4-bit) + adapters(fp32) = full fidelity
Pure Elixir tokenization approach
nodes.metadata_json:
{"branch":"main","confidence":90,"prompt":"User demanded NO PYTHON at runtime. The tokenization was using Python subprocess which was unacceptable. Options:
1. Keep Python subprocess (rejected outright)
2. Port Python tokenizer manually to Elixir
3. Use Bumblebee's tokenizer (Rust NIFs via Tokenizers library)

Fork of Bumblebee already existed one directory up."}

nodes.title: Keep Python subprocess for tokenization
Port Python tokenizer manually to Elixir
Use Bumblebee tokenizer (Rust NIFs)
Bumblebee tokenizer works - pure Elixir stack achieved

Fused model re-quantization destroys fine-tuning signal
nodes.metadata_json: {"branch":"main","confidence":100,"prompt":"The math: LoRA(fp16) + Base(4-bit) → merged → re-quantized to 4-bit = precision loss.\nThis is why the \"uncanny valley\" was happening - the fine-tuning was being destroyed.\nPython mlx_lm uses runtime LoRA, which is why it worked better."}
